subject: Design : Virtual Management Interface IP Configuration
commitMessage:
Design : Virtual Management Interface IP Configuration

This commit describes the BMC design to manage the Hypervisor
Ethernet Interface configuration

Signed-off-by: Sunitha Harish <sunithaharish04@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0463a894b77741caf5c1063ede3658fcc64369db

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> (1 comment)

I will update the document with the interfaces over the redfish.

Patch Set 2:

Hi all, 
Please review the proposed design for the VMI IP configuration. 
Thanks, Sunitha

Patch Set 3:

(17 comments)

Thank you for this commit Sunitha! I feel this needs a little work to be consumable by the community (non-IBMers). Some IBM lingo snuck in when it is not needed. Some IBM acronyms and terminology needs to be explained.

Patch Set 5:

What is the mechanism being used for transport of the packets / frames to the host?

Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

> What is the mechanism being used for transport of the packets /
 > frames to the host?

These are the REST commands which are over the Https. The endpoint of these commands are bmcweb.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> > What is the mechanism being used for transport of the packets /
>  > frames to the host?
> 
> These are the REST commands which are over the Https. The endpoint of these commands are bmcweb.

That doesn't really answer the question, what is the lower level mechanism for connecting the two endpoints? Just some kind of virtual network adapter?

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > (3 comments)
> > 
> > > What is the mechanism being used for transport of the packets /
> >  > frames to the host?
> > 
William, Outcome of these REST API would be to store this configuration in the BMC and the HOST would ask this info through PLDM(over LPC/PCIe). 
> > These are the REST commands which are over the Https. The endpoint of these commands are bmcweb.
> 
> That doesn't really answer the question, what is the lower level mechanism for connecting the two endpoints? Just some kind of virtual network adapter?

Patch Set 7:

Hi reviewers, Please review this design and share your comments. 
Thanks,Sunitha

Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)

Hi Reviewers, 

There are multiple changes in the last rework of this design. 
1. The Dbus objects to hold the IP addresses are updated as per the last discussion with the VMI&Phyp
2. The /ibm/v1/Host will hook up with the DMTF's EthernetInterface schemas.

Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

You are using Redfish schemas here but not implementing at a correct path and instead implementing at your own API.

Patch Set 12:

Updated the latest design - Modeling the VMI via the "hypervisor" System resource and the associated EthernetInterfaces property.

Please review and provide your votes.

we should not keep the file in /etc/systemd/network. This is the location where systemd keeps the network configuration.
We can use the /var/lib/ path for the host network configuration, currecntly we are keeping it over there.

Computer system schema have the ethernet interfaces, which represens the ethernet interfaces for the system.
=========================================================
EthernetInterfaces	
$ref	"http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/EthernetInterfaceCollection.json#/definitions/EthernetInterfaceCollection"
description	"A reference to the collection of Ethernet interfaces associated with this system."
==========================================================
Yes. With this, the redfish interface can be used for the VMI IP configuration. I will update the design and upload the next version.
we can have single GET commnad for the above.

How do we create the VMI interfaces? what would be the interface name? Are we hardcoding the interface names? 

which application would create the D-bus object for the VMI interface?

Currently, in BMC, phosphor-settings-manager creates the host network object so hardcoded the interface and the IP address, but in e-BMC we may have multiple NCSI interfaces.
Do we need to mention the MACaddress and the EthernetInterface here?

This is a PATCH request, why the action is there in the URL? I am hoping it should have been like below.

curl -c cjar -b cjar -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token -X PATCH 
https://${bmc}/xyz/openbmc_project/network/host0/eth0/ipv4/<objectId -d ‘{“data”: ["xyz.openbmc_project.Network.IP.Protocol.IPv4/IPv6", "address", "gateway","prefixlength"]}’
At line no-171 we were using the PATCH request to update the properties and here we are having the PUT request for updating the DHCP enabled property.

Currently, in BMC, phosphor-settings-manager creates the host network object which is consumed by the host through IPMI.
Now in ebmc where there could be multiple NCSI interfaces, how we are planning to handle this?

Same comments as I posted on another management console design. This document can probably be understood only by someone at IBM. It points to internal documents, uses internal acronyms, and does not provide a detailed background.

+1 Yeah, this is probably only going to be used by IBM but lets try and be a bit more generic. We can refer to VMI as a host based service partition (? partition may be IBM specific as well ?). And the goal of this design is for an external entity to be able to configure a network interface for that service partition. OpenBMC will provide the conduit to configure that network.
Agree. I will add the acronyms in this document. Also will change the statement to make it globally meaningful.
We don't even support full IPv6 on OpenBMC yet. Is that assumed to be done by the time we do this?
This was the requirement set taken/copied from the VMI requirement document. The design will consider to accommodate the IPv6 as well, when it comes in future.
Requirement did not mention that it should be the Redfish interface. The design will explain that the interface will be a redfish based.
Who is firmware? OpenBMC for persisting the info?
As mentioned earlier, this statement is taken from the requirement document. In this context the BMC is the firmware.
Is there any precedent for doing this in Redfish? The validator will be ok with this? Any need to engage DMTF?

The HostInterfaces parameter is already standardized by the DMTF
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Manager.v1_5_2.json
I think this should be HostEthernetInterfaces ?
This uri is as per the DMTF standard. We can not change the name of the parameter. This EthernetInterfaceCollection is under the HostInterfaces/<Id>/. So this interface is for the Host.
The type is EthernetInterfaceCollection but the property name is HostEthernetInterfaces per https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/HostInterface.v1_2_1.json
Maybe explain what VMI is? or atleast expand it here.
"Hardware Management Console (HMC)" since you later call it just HMC. Or move the glossary up?
POWER hypervisor (PHYP) or add to glossary
Virtual Management Interface (VMI) or move the glossary up? and/or maybe expand VMI in the title. Virtual Management Interface (VMI) IP Address Configuration
I think CEC is an IBM term.

This looks like: 

Requirements

1.BMC will provide an interface to allow the admin to get and set the VMI network configuration. 1.1 Support static/dynamic IPv4/IPv6 2.BMC will provide an interface for HMC to get the VMI network configuration (VMI discovery) 3.Any state required across a reboot must be provided by firmware 3.1 IP address configuration

Formatted. Could you run through a markdown editor like https://jbt.github.io/markdown-editor/
Since these are curl commands can you put code blocks around these? ``` ```
nitpick: JSON if you want to change. Don't have to.
nitpick: D-Bus. if you want to change. Don't have to.

VMI can not work with multiple IP address. But the redfish provides a way to configure multiple values for the IP addresses. So if VMI is configured with multiple IP addresses, the last configured IP will be the active IP.

This would look a lot better in a code block. Like: 
``` json

http://www.rubycoloredglasses.com/2013/04/languages-supported-by-github-flavored-markdown/
spelling? existing. I would recommend a grammar/spelling checker. I would recommend app.grammarly.com or Microsoft office.
Can you call this glossary like https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/23054/8/designs/open_power_boot_manager.md and expand a bit? Also move up in the document

Add new lines between these, otherwise markup formats like:
##Acronyms VMI - Virtual Management Interface BMC - Baseboard Management System HMC - Hardware Management System

Tested with https://jbt.github.io/markdown-editor/

Controller ?
Otherwise, this would define BMS.
I know one thing that came up was to support a change to the VMI IP address while the system was up and running. Sub-bullet to number 1?
I believe decision from workshop was to move this under ${bmc}/ibm/v1?
Yes. I will change the urls to the /ibm/v1

as we have the single default gateway entry and we are supporting ipv4/ipv6.
Do we need two default gateway entry?
What is the use of mask here?
this is the logical name for the VMI interface , like eth0, eth1 etc.
How this gateway is different from the line no 71(Default Gateway)?
yes. This is the gateway specific to this IP address subnet. If this is not configured, then the DefaultGateway will be used.
As the VMI is supporting the single IP address, Can we have single ipv4 address object having all the properties?

as per the VMI spec there would be two ip address(ipv4/ipv6) per interface
Can we have ip address object created with empty values?
ibm/v1/VMI/network/<interface>/ipv4/addr
ibm/v1/VMI/network/<interface>/ipv6/addr

If we say that this object always exist then it would be PUT request.
Since its a POST , i added the action keyword. I will change it to PUT, and we can have the default all 0 IP address in the BMC.

we don't have any xyz interfaces in future.
Can we just say IPv4/Ipv6?
why attr? Can we use the PATCH request?

gateway is not needed.
subnet mask is not there, same as prefix length

remove attr.
And make this API looks like redfish.
PATCH -d {"DHCPEnabled:"true} https://${bmc}/ibm/v1/VMInterface/network/<Id>
why enumerate? I am surprised to see "enumerate" in a new API. I thought we would be moving away from "enumerate" in any new API.
Can we just call it hypervisor?
Named it VMInterface , to map it easily to the VMI tag which we have in the requirement and other high level designs.

I feel making these "flat" like the Redfish EthernetInterface model is better than having an objectId/using enumerate. 

/ibm/v1/hypervisor/network/eth0 
/ibm/v1/hypervisor/network/0 
or maybe just /ibm/v1/hypervisor/network

This IntfId and objectID is listed here to indicate that there can be multiple interfaces like eth0 , eth1 etc.. with multiple IP addresses on them with objectId1, objectId2 ...and so on.
The BMC design supports this model, though we have limitations at VMI to support single IP for its interface. Intention is to anticipate less changes if the requirement scales up in future.
remove the -c cjar.. Don't need to write a cookie for these. Above and below as well.
It is or it's. Maybe something more like "Since the Power Hypervisor only supports a single IP address, it is recommended to only configure one IP address."

Why can't you use the Redfish EthernetInterface Schema?
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/EthernetInterface_v1.xml
It could be at  /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/EthernetInterfaces/{EthernetInterfaceId} ?
Could we create a "Hypervisor" System? Can we ask the DMTF where a Hypervisor Network information should go?

The VMI Interface are designed in REST way as discussed in the workshop. 
The DMTF describes many parameters for the EthernetInterface & ComputerSystem resources which are not used in the VMI interface. 
This is ideally the Phyp console which is open only for the HMC. This can not be modeled as the actual "host".

We are coming up with a schema for all the HMC-BMC interface REST commands, which will include this VMI network schema as well.

> The VMI Interface are designed in REST way as discussed in the workshop.


What workshop?

> The DMTF describes many parameters for the EthernetInterface & ComputerSystem resources which are not used in the VMI interface. 


Almost all are optional, you don't need to use the ones you don't need.

If we use something standard for this, we don't have to invent all these interfaces and properties. Redfish has a lot of document, well estiblished community. Calling this from like the GUI becomes a lot easier.

It was discussed in the India workshop(August 2019),that the IBM specific management console use-cases will be implemented in REST way.
With the IBM specific HMC use-cases, we will be having two root services - /redfish/v1 and /ibm/v1. Both will have their own metadata implementations. 
We are working on some POC to pull in the references to the standard redfish EthernetInterface schema into the /ibm/v1/ root.
This doesn't seem to map 1x1 with the PLDM BIOS attributes for VMI config documented at https://ibm.ent.box.com/file/478139954961
My Bad. This is showing up like this here. I will set this diagram right.
need to change, it is /redfish/v1 now.

This is a Redfish schema, but implemented outside the acceptable paths . This would throw a validator error. 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/EthernetInterfaceCollection_v1.xml

We have plugged in the EthernetInterface collection and the resources to the /ibm/v1/Host path. 

This is to avoid the impact to the user interfaces - both HMC & GUI. They can now use the same APIs for configuring the BMC interface and the VMI interface. The only change here is the URL path.

When it comes to redfish validator - The interfaces under /ibm/v1 are IBM only. So i believe that we need not be in line with the redfish validator.

Redfish validator neven runs on the /ibm/v1, default path is /redfish/v1.
Anyways we have decided that 
=> Create one more system named a hypervisor 
=> Configure the ethernet interface under that system.

Redfish dropped this, I think you should as well 
https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/commit/d446de8a86c2cba5a5d5c3090cba718617c55790
I can not access this path. It complains as Not Found
This is a Redfish schema, but implemented outside the acceptable paths https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/EthernetInterface_v1.xml. This would throw a validator error
Why not use Redfish's ComputerSystem? Why dup work?

The VMI can not be modeled as ComputerSystem , since it does not have the characteristics of a complete Host. We don't want to expose this VMI to all the customers, which may lead to create an impression in the community as we are modeling the Host(linux/aix etc) itself. 

There is no duplication of the work. The EthernetInterfaceCollection is plugged under the /ibm/v1/host to minimize the bmcweb,HMC and GUI work.

Can you confirm here that you're using existing D-Bus interfaces for this work?  It appears that you are from the list below, but it isn't obvious.  You should specify which interfaces are being implemented.  You've mentioned paths and properties but you're missing interface names.
